subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS news update
msgSnippet: Ah, now I remember that you already explained this. Thanks for taking the time to repeat yourself. Eventually, as I suggested earlier, I think we ll need
messageBody:
Ah, now I remember that you already explained this. Thanks for taking
the time to repeat yourself.

Eventually, as I suggested earlier, I think we'll need curators to
represent each accent we want to include in the dictionary.

How do you handle multiple entries? For example, I found the spelling
of "accidentally" in today's news strange because to me it appeared to
be missing a 'Tut'. But looking in the dictionary I see this:

ACCIDENTALLY AE2 K S AH0 D EH1 N T AH0 L IY0
ACCIDENTALLY(2) AE2 K S AH0 D EH1 N AH0 L IY0

Another reference that may be useful is the Unifon dictionary:
http://www.unifon.org/dictionary.htm
http://66.41.57.23/UFLookup/UNIFON%20dict.pdf

Ted


On Nov 13, 2007 9:53 AM, Paul Tremblay <phthenry@...> wrote:
>
>
>
>
>
>
> Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> >
> >
> > Hi Paul,
> >
> > I continue to be quite impressed by your news transliteration program.
> > To err on the side of having too many name dots is fine--it doesn't
> > slow me down at all, whereas having too few did.
> >
> > Could you tell us how you are handling the CMU phonemes? Looking at
> > the first paragraph of today's American news, I see that "Robert" is
> > written with #32 while "Washington" is written with #33. In the second
> > sentence, "drop" is written with #34. Looking these words up in the
> > CMU dictionary:
> >
> > ROBERT R AA1 B ER0 T
> > WASHINGTON W AA1 SH IH0 NG T AH0 N
> > DROP D R AA1 P
> >
> > They all use 'AA', the "odd" phoneme. This makes me wonder--are you
> > using a different dictionary now? If not, you must have a more
> > sophisticated algorithm than simple one-to-one substitution.
> >
> > Here are the CMU entries for the relevant lexical sets:
> >
> > LOT L AA1 T
> > CLOTH K L AO1 TH
> > THOUGHT TH AO1 T
> > PALM P AA1 M
> >
> > I would have been inclined to use #32 for 'AA' and #33 for 'AO'.
> >
>
> Hi Ted,
>
> Thanks for the compliments. For the CMU dictionary, I am using Ah (#32)
> for AA and Awl (#33) for AO, exactly as you would. That should be
> happening, anyway. However, I have a personal dictionary that overrides
> the CMU dictionary. The personal dictionary right now consists of the
> 2000 most commonly used words in the English language, as well as about
> 400 more that I have used in transliteration some Grimm's fairy tales.
> To create my personal dictionary, I took the 2000 words from CMU and
> corrected what I thought were mistakes. I used my American Heritage
> Dictionary to look up the pronunciations of such words as "pot," because
> I can't distinguish between "On" and "Awl."
>
> I use "Ah," "Awl," and "On," in my personal dictionary, since my
> American Heritage Dictionary makes that distinction. My newer Longman
> dictionary does not. I hope that we who are working on defining lexical
> sets can decide what to do in situations like this. After a while,
> alphabets get defined on how they are used, just as our TO alphabet did.
> So I want to use QS that is reasonable and readable for everyone.
>
> You will notice some inconsistencies in the news. Since my personal
> dictionary contains the *most* commonly used words, you may see a lot of
> words spelled with "On" whereas a word right next to it, that rhymes,
> and that is taken from the CMU dictionary, uses "Awl" or "Ahh." Another
> inconsistency, however, occurs because the CMU dictionary contains
> errors. I don't just mean different ways of pronouncing words than I
> have, but outright errors such as putting a "b" before an "r." I think
> these errors also carry over to some of the vowel choices as well.
>
> If you have suggestions on word choice (and this applies to anyone), and
> you want to make a change, just send me a text file with the TO word on
> the left, followed by some space, followed by the QS word in ASCII. For
> example:
>
> grass grAs
> birdfeeder bardfIdar
>
> The more people that submit corrected words, the more accurate the
> dictionary and the news.
>
> Paul
>

Ah, now I remember that you already explained this. Thanks for taking
the time to repeat yourself.

Eventually, as I suggested earlier, I think we'll need curators to
represent each accent we want to include in the dictionary.

How do you handle multiple entries? For example, I found the spelling
of "accidentally" in today's news strange because to me it appeared to
be missing a 'Tut'. But looking in the dictionary I see this:

ACCIDENTALLY  AE2 K S AH0 D EH1 N T AH0 L IY0
ACCIDENTALLY(2)  AE2 K S AH0 D EH1 N AH0 L IY0

Another reference that may be useful is the Unifon dictionary:
http://www.unifon.org/dictionary.htm
http://66.41.57.23/UFLookup/UNIFON%20dict.pdf

Ted
